reasoning: First off, Netflix isn’t in my circle of competence. I’ve spent my life buying simple, predictable businesses—I know fizzy drinks, insurance and railroads, not streaming platforms in an ever-changing tech landscape. Next, while Netflix shows strong operating margins and some pricing power, its return on equity has only averaged 7.7%—hardly a durable moat when you need 15%-plus in good years. Management hasn’t issued much stock or paid dividends, which is fine, but they’ve loaded up the balance sheet with a debt-to-equity ratio of about 3.0. That makes me uneasy when interest rates rise. The company’s earnings growth is inconsistent, too—zero points for steadiness, despite a 148% jump over ten periods. On valuation, the three-stage DCF pegs a conservative intrinsic value near $8,600 a share, yet Netflix trades well above that—leaving a deeply negative margin of safety. Long term, fierce competition from deep-pocketed rivals and the streaming arms race cloud the outlook. Given the 10% discount rate I use and better opportunities in my portfolio—from Coca-Cola’s pricing power to Apple’s sticky ecosystem—I’m going to pass. There’s no shame in walking away from a business I don’t fully understand or at a price I can’t justify.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 7.7%; High debt to equity ratio of 3.0; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of 148.2% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 0/10 periods >15%; Strong and stable operating margins (avg: 38.8%) indicate pricing power moat; High performance stability (82.9%) suggests strong competitive moat

book_value_analysis.details: Consistent book value per share growth (Buffett's favorite metric)

management_analysis.details: No significant new stock issuance detected; No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (8.0%, 5y), Stage 2 (4.0%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
